711107f-a.text:
(1)
11th Street (formerly Hammond Street), south side, east from and including West 4th Street, St. Vincent's Hospital in the background, on the N.E. corner of Seventh Avenue and the true West 11th Street. The classical temple at 220, the S.E. corner of Waverly Place, is the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John the Evangelist (1856).
August 6, 1932.
P. L. Sperr

(2)
The same, the following spring. This apparent intersection at right angles of two supposedly parallel streets has already been explained in describing 4th Street north from the corner of 10th Street. Neither of these streets was numbered when originally laid out. This part of 4th Street has been West 4th Street since probably 1820, but Hammond Street did not lose its name till around 1870.
Latterly this crossing has become dangerous, so there is a special traffic light on the N.E. corner.
May 20, 1933.
P. L. Sperr

711107f-b.text:
(1)
11th Street (formerly Hammond Street), south side, east from and including West 4th Street, St. Vincent's Hospital in the background, on the N.E. corner of Seventh Avenue and the true West 11th Street. The classical temple at 220, the S.E. corner of Waverly Place, is the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John the Evangelist (1856).
August 6, 1932.
P. L. Sperr

(2)
The same, the following spring. This apparent intersection at right angles of two supposedly parallel streets has already been explained in describing 4th Street north from the corner of 10th Street. Neither of these streets was numbered when originally laid out. This part of 4th Street has been West 4th Street since probably 1820, but Hammond Street did not lose its name till around 1870.
Latterly this crossing has become dangerous, so there is a special traffic light on the N.E. corner.
May 20, 1933.
P. L. Sperr

711098f-a.text:
11th Street, south side, east from North Baptist Church at 232 West 11th Street (formerly about 32 Hammond Street), between 4th Street and Waverly Place. The classical building on the S.E. corner of Waverly Place is St. John the Evangelist (Protestant Episcopal). On the S.W. corner of 11th Street and Greenwich Avenue the old Continental Brewery was demolished around 1914 when Seventh Avenue South was opened. St. Vincent's Hospital, 153 West 11th Street at Seventh Avenue, is seen in the background.

This part of 11th Street, parallel to Charles, Perry, and Bank Streets, lost its own name around 1870, and was renumbered as a continuation of the true 11th Street, which is all east of Seventh Avenue.

May 20, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

711099f-a.text:
242-208 West 11th Street, south side, from east of 4th Street to
Seventh Avenue South.
The North Baptist Church (1882) is shown at 236-2 West 11th Street, and the Church of St. John the Evangelist (Protestant Episcopal, built 1856) at 220, at the S.W. corner of Waverly Place. A bit of St. Vincent's Hospital, on the N.E. corner of Seventh Avenue and the true West 11th Street, is visible in the background.
Mey 2O, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

711108f-a.text:
11th Street (originally Hammond Street), at S.W. corner of 4th Street (originally Lord knows what!), Greenwich Village. 258 West 11th Street, the little one-story studio adjoining the corner, is supposed to be really quite old ("very old" in Greenwich Village
means about 1820 or earlier).
May 20, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

710914f-a.text:
279-281 West 4th Street, adjoining the S.E. corner of 11th Street (formerly Hammond Street). The Ship Shape Inn, at 281, is a
typical Greenwich Village restaurant.
May 12, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

710924f-a.text:
W. 4th Street, at the N. E. corner af W. 11th Street.
Ootober 9, 1939
George b. Chinn

711109f-a.text:
West 11th Street, at the N.E. corner of W. 4th Street.

1938-9

Alexander Alland

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N.Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.
